definition: A call option gives the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to buy an underlying asset at a specified strike price before the option expires.
A put option gives the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to sell an underlying asset at a specified strike price before expiration.
A metric that reflects the market's forecast of a likely movement in a security's price. Higher IV means higher expected movement and usually higher option premiums.
The total number of outstanding option contracts that are open and not yet settled. It helps gauge liquidity and activity in an option.
